question.title: Which Party will win the 2026 Gorton and Denton by-election?
question.description:
Following the [2024 United Kingdom general election](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2024_United_Kingdom_general_election), Labour Party leader Keir Starmer became Prime Minister. During his tenure, he has faced [dramatic declines](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opinion_polling_for_the_next_United_Kingdom_general_election) in both party and personal polling, reaching unprecedented levels of personal unpopularity and seeing the Labour Party fall below 20% support.

As Starmer's popularity has declined, speculation has emerged that he may face a challenge for the Labour leadership and be ousted as Prime Minister. Mayor of Greater Manchester [Andy Burnham](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andy_Burnham) has often been considered one of the top contenders to challenge Starmer, being strongly approved of by Manchester residents and one of the very few British politicians with a positive national approval rating.

Due to not holding a seat in the House of Commons, Andy Burnham would need to win a by-election before he could become Prime Minister. On January 22, 2026, and following months of speculation, Andrew Gwynne, Labour MP for Gorton and Denton [announced his resignation](https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/articles/c14rrez0mr4o). Though he cited ill health, it is generally thought that he resigned to allow Andy Burnham to run.

Although Burnham was widely considered the strongest Labour candidate for the seat, the Starmer-aligned National Executive Committee [blocked his Labour candidacy](https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/articles/czr4e7ep468o), throwing the race into significant contention.

The election follows substantial Labour losses in recent by-elections, including to Reform in the [2025 Runcorn and Helsby by-election](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2025_Runcorn_and_Helsby_by-election) and to Plaid Cymru in the Senedd [2025 Caerphilly by-election](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2025_Caerphilly_by-election). Despite Gorton and Denton being traditionally considered a safe Labour seat, both Reform UK and the Green Party are considered [serious](https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/labour-greens-gorton-denton-byelection-b2908838.html) [contenders](https://theconversation.com/gorton-and-denton-byelection-labour-won-comfortably-in-2024-but-reform-could-benefit-from-a-split-vote-on-the-left-274672).

`{"format":"metac_reveal_and_close_in_period","info":{"post_id":41951,"question_id":41690}}`
question.resolution_criteria: This question will resolve as the party of the winner of the [2026 Gorton and Denton by-election](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2026_Gorton_and_Denton_by-election).
question.fine_print:
If an independent or a member of a party other than one of the listed parties wins the election, this question will resolve as Other.

If the 2026 Gorton and Denton by-election is not held or the winner is otherwise not known before May 1, 2026, this question will be annulled.

***
This question's information (resolution criteria, fine print, background info, etc) is synced with an [original identical question](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/41951) which opened on 2026-02-04 17:00:00. This question will resolve based on the resolution criteria and fine print contained above. However, if this question would resolve differently than the original question, then this question will be annulled. Additionally, if the original question's resolution could have been known before this question opened, then this question will be annulled.
